Our Constitution has enshrined equal protection under the law; making Juneteenth a federal holiday will give us all the opportunity to reflect on what that means and how to protect this principle for generations to come.
Slavery was a colossal evil, and inflicted great pain on Black Americans.

I love this great country of ours, & we have always shown an incredible capacity to learn from our mistakes and do what is right. As Pres George W. Bush said, "the price of our Union was America's original sin," and the fact is that our country didn't afford liberty to everyone.

After Confederate Gen. Lee surrendered, Union Gen. Gordon Granger's arrival in Galveston helped spread the message that war was over and enslaved people were free. Celebrations broke out among newly freed Black Americans in the south, & the day known as Juneteenth was born.

The Emancipation Proclamation didn't free all who were enslaved. It only applied to areas under Confederate control, not former Confederate territory that was taken by the Union or slave-holding border states.

The Emancipation Proclamation, issued two years earlier on January 1, 1863, established that all enslaved people "shall be then, thenceforward, and forever free." 

However, slavery remained relatively unhindered in Texas.
Juneteenth, recognized every year on 6/19, marks the day in 1865 when Union soldiers arrived in Galveston, TX, to take control of the state and ensure that enslaved people would be free.

[THREAD] I proudly voted to support making #Juneteenth a federal holiday. This day is central to U.S. history, the day the final enslaved Black Americans learned they had been freed. It's a celebration of liberty, freedom, & resilience in the face of the terrible evil of slavery. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E4CvZrZXoAAsgQz.jpg

But by tackling the climate risk head-on, not only will we safeguard our economy against the #ClimateCrisis, but we‚Äôll unleash the power of our entrepreneurs, save taxpayer dollars, create jobs, and leave a better planet for our kids than the one we inherited from our parents.

The #ClimateCrisis is also changing long-term climate patterns in ways that will:
üìâLower labor productivity 
üìâDevalue and destroy fixed assets 
üìâStress agricultural yields 
üìâUltimately disrupt every sector of our economy

Failing to take sufficient action on #ClimateRisk will result in devastation we cannot afford right now. Raging wildfires, droughts, blackouts, and superstorms have already caused over $500 billion in damages in the past four years and will only get worse.
https://www.swissre.com/media/news-releases/nr-20210422-economics-of-climate-change-risks.html

The #ClimateRiskDisclosure Act is a common-sense, market-based solution that will: 
‚úÖRequire companies to be transparent about their exposures.
‚úÖMitigate risk and shine a light on the enormous threat to our financial system posed by #ClimateChange.

I introduced the Climate Risk Disclosure Act with @SenWarren to require public companies to disclose climate-related risks‚Äîempowering investors to make smarter decisions & harnessing the power of free markets as we build towards a cleaner, cheaper economy. https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/climate-risks-bill-could-spark-shift-to-truly-green-economy/
But because public companies have no obligation to disclose their exposure to climate-related risks, investors are left in the dark.

Through rising sea levels, forest fires, increasingly frequent extreme weather, water shortages & resource scarcity, the #ClimateCrisis directly threatens valuable assets.
https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/08/climate/climate-change-financial-markets.html

Markets are an incredibly powerful tool to ease the transition from fossil fuels to clean, cheap energy. But efficient markets depend on transparent information.

Here‚Äôs why my Climate Risk Disclosure Act is a win for capitalism, a win for consumers & a win for the planet.

I am concerned that if inflation is not transitory, the Fed will be behind the curve and likely unable to respond in time to head off an even bigger problem down the road.
When you subordinate the price stability mandate to try and maximize employment, you run the risk of failing on both fronts because you need stable prices to achieve a strong economy.

It is clear the labor market, which cannot be micromanaged by the Fed, is being held back by policymakers. It is not the Fed‚Äôs job to attempt to offset flawed unemployment policy at the expense of its price stability mandate.

With more job openings than people looking for work, the economy could quickly move a long way toward full employment if the Biden administration and congressional Democrats did not insist on paying people more in unemployment benefits than they make working.
Today‚Äôs announcement shows the Fed is continuing to prioritize maximum employment over controlling inflation.
